title: The Dow Rose 74 Points Because Momentum Stocks Have Lost Some Mojo
text:
Text size

Losing Momentum. U.S. stocks had a mixed performance on Tuesday. Treasury yields recovered, momentum stocks sold off, and value stocks rose. Apple stock (ticker: AAPL) ended flat after the company announced its new iPhone 11. Ford Motor stock (F) tumbled after credit-ratings firm Moody’s downgraded the auto maker’s bonds to junk status. Uber Technologies (UBER) and Lyft (LYFT) jumped despite a pending California bill that would classify ride-share drivers as employees. The initial public offering of WeWork’s parent company is in question after the valuation was slashed and its biggest outside investor raised concerns. In today’s After the Bell, we...

watch Treasury yields continue to rise from last week’s cycle low;

explore the impact of a changing sentiment on different market corners;

and explain why a California bill might catch the ride-sharing giants in a jam.

Diverging Trend

All three major indexes ended little changed from Monday, but performance across the different market corners diverged significantly. The Dow Jones Industrial Average added 73.92 points, or 0.28%, to close at 26,909.43. The S&P 500 edged up 0.96 points, or 0.03%, to finish at 2979.39, and the Nasdaq Composite slipped 3.28 points, or 0.04%, to close at 8084.16.

As headlines about the U.S.-China trade war wind down, and the two sides prepare for the next round of negotiations in October, investors’ fears seem to have subsided, as well.

After falling sharply throughout August, yields on 10-year Treasury notes started to show signs of a rebound from last week, increasing 25 basis points to 1.706% this Tuesday from the all-time low of 1.461% last Tuesday. Both the 10-year and 30-year Treasury yields have hit one-month highs; prices and yields move in the opposite directions.

A recovering sentiment and rising bond yields have had different impacts on different market corners. Bank stocks, whose revenue and profitability rely on interest rates on loans, continued their weeklong rally on Tuesday, with the SPDR S&P Bank ETF (KBE) rising 1.7% at close. On the other hand, the real-estate investment trust stocks in the S&P 500 tumbled 1.5%. The sector is traditionally considered “bond proxy” due to its high dividend payment. As bond yields go up, it appears less attractive for income seekers.

Editor's Choice

The sudden shift in sentiment has also caused some pain in momentum stocks, which were once the market’s best performers, while boosting value stocks, which have underperformed for almost a decade. At the same time, the price of gold retreated to $1,496.20 per ounce on Tuesday from its seven-year high of $1,560.40 last week. Still, some analysts believe the precious metal can soar all the way to $2,000 per ounce, and post new cyclical highs at some point in the next year or two,

The Wall Street Journal reported that California Democrats are poised to pass a landmark legislation that would classify some contract workers as employees, which would entitle them to benefits such as a minimum hourly wage and workers’ compensation. The bill would apply to workers in many industries from truck drivers to music workers, but two Silicon Valley companies—ride-sharing giants Uber and Lyft—would likely be affected the most.

Both companies’ business models rely on large pools of contractors, and they have spent much of the year pushing back on the bill. Uber and Lyft claim the bill would introduce additional costs to passengers and take away the job flexibility most drivers desire. Their effort has failed against opposition from labor unions and a large Democratic majority in Sacramento. The bill, if passed, will take effect next January.

Uber and Lyft both went public this year, and their stock performances haven’t been ideal. Still, the two stocks jumped 3.9% and 2.4%, respectively, on Tuesday as investors largely shrugged off the news that’s already been in play for months.

Write to Evie Liu at evie.liu@barrons.com
description: Stocks had a mixed performance on Tuesday. Treasury yields recovered, momentum stocks sold off, and value stocks rose. Apple ended flat after the company announced its new iPhone 11. Ford tumbled after its bonds were downgraded to junk status.
